metadata.description: Heidegger - Being and Time pages 22-23 with translator footnotes. Tests OCR corruption resistance and superscript numeral detection. Only 2 footnotes detectable from PDF text layer due to OCR issues with markers 2 and 3.

definition.content: 'Sein liegt im Dass- und Sosein, in Realität, Vorhandenheit, Bestand, Geltung, Dasein, im "es gibt".' On 'Vorhandenheit' ('presence-at-hand') see note 1, p. 48, H. 25. On 'Dasein', see note 1, p. 27.

The word 'Dasein' plays so important a role in this work and is already so familiar to the English-speaking reader who has read about Heidegger, that it seems simpler to leave it untranslated except in the relatively rare passages in which Heidegger himself breaks it up with a hyphen ('Da-sein') to show its etymological construction: literally 'Being-there'. Though in traditional German philosophy it may be used quite generally to stand for almost any kind of Being or 'existence' which we can say that something has (the 'existence' of God, for example), in everyday usage it tends to be used more narrowly to stand for the kind of Being that belongs to persons. Heidegger follows the everyday usage in this respect, but goes somewhat further in that he often uses it to stand for any person who has such Being, and who is thus an 'entity' himself. See H. 11 below.

notes: Ground truth designed to test ISSUE-FN-002 (false positive detection). OCR corruption markers (~ and ·) must NOT be detected as footnotes. All footnotes are Macquarrie & Robinson translator notes. Only 2 footnotes detectable from PDF text layer - markers 2 and 3 were OCR'd incorrectly. Ground truth updated 2025-11-24 after programmatic verification of PDF text layer.
